Only recently did a field of medicine dedicated to sleep emerge.   Recent advances in neuroimaging and the development of new plasma and cerebrospinal biomarkers are increasing the prominence of a neuroscientific perspective in sleep research. The fundamental questions in the study of sleep remain largely to be clarified:   Why do we sleep?   What happens in the brain during sleep?   What are the consequences of disturbed sleep on the brain?   The Sleep, Aging, and Memory (SAM) Lab is a program developed by a consortium lead by three groups of investigators from the Center for Brain Health ( Ricardo Osorio, MD ), NYU Sleep Disorders Center (Indu Ayappa, PhD), and the Center for Neural Science (Andrew Varga, MD, PhD). Our mission is to try to solve these and other issues related to sleep, normal aging, memory processing, and the risk for Alzheimer’s disease. Designed to promote research and foster collaboration on broad scale research projects focused on brain aging, geriatrics, dementia science and neurodegenerative diseases, the program was attended by more than 160 guests and the poster session included 44 posters representing more than a dozen departments and schools spanning the NYU Langone network.       The introduction by Ralph A. Nixon, Ph.D., M.D., Director of the CCN and Silberstein Alzheimer's Institute, focused on the expansion of the CCN; the launch of the Center's biorepository program led by Dr. Thomas Wisniewski; and the Center's commitment to further developing its junior investigators. He also noted that the CCN is on track to receive a record level of funding this year, despite dismal prospects of the sequestration. In addition, Dr. Nixon honed-in on the importance of advocacy and encouraged the audience to be part of our outreach effort. Following the opening remarks, Dr. Nixon presented the Blas Frangione Young Investigator Merit Award to Charles Hoeffer, Ph.D, for his novel and ground-breaking research on the tau protein, synaptic plasticity and GABAergic function.       Key presenters were:       o Charles Hoeffer, PhD, Assistant Professor, Department of Neuroscience and Physiology;   o Donald Wilson, PhD Research Professor, Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, Senior Research Scientist, Emotional Brain Institute, Nathan Kline Institute;   o Caroline Blaum, MD, MS, Diane and Arthur Belfer Professor of Geriatrics, Director, Division of Geriatrics, Department of Medicine;   o Peter Davies, PhD, Judith and Burton P. Resnick Professor, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Director, Litwin-Zucker Center Feinstein Institute for Medical Research, North Shore LIJ.         2013 Poster Session Winners         Winning Poster in Basic/Translational Research:   Henrieta Scholtzova, PhD   "Innate Immunity Stimulation as a Novel Therapeutic Approach in AD"   Co-Authors: PN Nehete, R Sabado, E Do, F Kuo, Y Sun, PE Chianchiano, LE Williams, T Wisniewski       Winning Poster in Clinical Research:   Els Fieremans, PhD   "Novel White Matter Tract Integrity Metrics Sensitive to Alzheimer's Disease Progression"   Co-Authors: A Benitez, JH Jensen, MF Falangola, A Tabesh, RL Deardorff, JS Babb, DS Novikov, SH Ferris, JA Helpern       Honorable Mentions: Aíne Duffy, PhD, Sarah Johnson, PhD, Mala Rao, PhD, Sandrine Sanchez, PhD, Marissa Schafer, MS       We thank Blas Frangione and the Frangione Foundation for making the Young Investigator Merit Award possible, as well as all those who were part of the Award nomination process and the selection committee for their review and input; the applications were of a high caliber and represented a diverse cross section of brain aging research at NYU. Additionally, many thanks also to the judging team during the poster session.                             2012 Center for Cognitive Neurology Research Day   March 7th, 2012     Photography Credit: Kamilika Roy   The CCN on Brain Aging hosted its third annual Research Day on March 7. Designed to promote research and foster collaboration on broad scale research projects focused on brain aging, geriatrics, dementia science and neurodegenerative diseases, the program was attended by more than 150 guests and the poster session included nearly 40 posters representing 10 departments and schools spanning the NYU Langone network.   The introduction by Ralph A. Nixon, Ph.D., M.D., Director of the CCN, focused on the expansion of the Center and the achievements accomplished within the past year. Opening remarks were made by Richard Tsien, D.Phil., Druckenmiller Professor of Neuroscience and Neural Science; Director of the NYU Neuroscience Institute; and Chair, Department of Physiology and Neuroscience.   Key presenters were:   Guang Yang, PhD, Assistant Professor, Department of Anesthesiology, NYU   Els Fieremans, PhD, Assistant Professor, Department of Radiology, NYU   Eric Klann, PhD, Professor, Center for Neural Science, NYU   Karen Duff, PhD, Professor, Taub Institute for Alzheimer Disease Research, Columbia University Medical Center, Department of Integrative Neuroscience, New York State Psychiatric Institute, Columbia University Medical Center   The program ended with Dr. Nixon presenting the Blas Frangione Young Investigator Merit Award to Guang Yang, PhD, recognizing her research focused on understanding the mechanism of synaptic loss and cognitive dysfunction in aging and neurodegenerative diseases.   2012 Poster Session Winners:   First Place : Tao Ma, MD, PhD   “Repression of PERK signaling alleviates impairments of synaptic plasticity and spatial memory in a transgenic mouse model of Alzheimer’s disease.” Co-Authors: MA Wong, DR Cavener, E Klann.   Second Place : Benjamin Winthrop Little, BA   “Non-invasive evaluation of tau targeted immunotherapy: a tract-tracing bolus memri study” Co-Authors: U Khan, H Rajamohamedsait, LK Hill, L Pendery, D Minh Hoang, EM Sigurdsson, and YZ Wadghiri.   Honorable Mentions: Ayodeji Asuni, PhD, Els Fieremans, PhD, Christian Lee, PhD, Marissa Schafer, MS, Henrieta Scholtzova, MD, PhD, Kinlung Wong, BA   2011 Center for Cognitive Neurology Research Day   February 16th, 2011                  Photography Credit: René Perez   The CCN on Brain Aging hosted its second annual Research Day on Wednesday, February 16. Designed to promote research and foster collaboration on broad scale research projects focused on brain aging, geriatrics, dementia science and neurodegenerative diseases, the program was attended by approximately 200 guests, including investigators, clinicians and faculty spanning the NYU Langone network.   The introduction by Ralph A. Nixon, Ph.D., M.D., Director of the CCN, focused on the expansion of the CCN and the achievements accomplished within the past year. He also honed-in on the 22 percent increase in the grant base, from 2009-2010, which by all accounts is significant given the downturn in the economy and its effect on research funding.   Vice Dean for Science, Vivian S. Lee, M.D., Ph.D., M.B.A., provided opening remarks which focused on the key role the CCN plays within NYU Langone and she praised members of the CCN and Dr. Nixon for its success.   Key presenters at this year’s Research Day were:   Helen E. Scharfman, Ph.D., “Initial pathophysiological events in Alzheimer’s disease: New Insights from Mouse AD models and their Clinical Implications”   Daniel Wesson, Ph.D., “The Smelly Facts about Early Neural Network Dysfunction in Alzheimer’s Disease”   Margaret E. Rice, Ph.D., “New Insights into the Puzzle of Parkinson’s Disease”   Berislav Zlovkovic, M.D., Ph.D., “Cellular and Molecular Mechanisms of Vascular-Mediated Neurodegeneration: Implications for Alzheimer’s and ALS”   The program ended with Dr. Nixon presenting the CCN’s Scientific Achievement Award to Blas Frangione, M.D., Ph.D.   The poster session, held in the lobby of the Smilow Research Center, incorporated more than 40 posters from CCN researchers and investigators across the NYU Langone universe. Judging the posters were: Drs. Ralph Nixon, Helen Scharfman, Margaret Rice, James Galvin, Steven Ferris, Thomas Wisniewski and Barry Reisberg.   2011 Poster Session Winners:   First Place : Allal Boutajangout, PhD   Second Place: Nunzio Pomara, MD   Honorable Mentions : Fernando Goni, PhD, Áine Duffy, PhD, Keria Bermudez-Hernandez, BS, Ipe Ninan, PhD, Seonil Kim, MS, Elizabeth Guerrero-Berroa, PhD                  Photography Credit: René Perez   The CCN on Brain Aging, a comprehensive, fully-integrated medical facility, is devoted to research and clinical advances toward the treatment and cure of all neurodegenerative diseases affecting cognition, with expertise in healthy brain aging; Alzheimer’s disease and memory disorders; Parkinson’s disease and movement disorders; atypical dementias; and geriatric psychiatry. Built upon the strengths of NYU  Langone’s Silberstein Alzheimer’s Institute and the former Comprehensive Center on Brain Aging, our research programs and clinical care centers are devoted to the prevention, treatment and cure of Alzheimer’s disease, Lewy body dementia, prion diseases, vascular dementia, traumatic brain injury, frontotemporal dementia, hydrocephalus, and autism.                                                            Research                     Areas of Research   Achievements in Research   Join a Research Study   Training        More               About Us                     Mission and Vision   Donate   Contact Us        More               Contact Us                    More                                                                                     Quick Links       The Pearl I.
